class_notes:
(Same as AAS 385 5, CPLT 389 6)
This course seeks to familiarize students on Afro-pessimism, one of the leading intellectual movements in critical black theories today, through film, art, and poetics. In doing so, the course examines what scholar, Frank Wilderson, has described as the gratuitous nature of anti-black violence and the political ontology of black social death. With these topics (as just a few examples) in mind, the course specifically interrogates aesthetics as a field of representation whence blackness and anti-blackness might be a specter to the borders and frames of its field. The course also draws on psychoanalytic, feminist, and literary theories as a way to approach the artistic works under examination. Bearing questions on the political and ethical brought into sharp focus by Afro-pessimism alongside continental and popular understandings of aesthetics, the course, in turn, attempts to think about the strictures that ?aesthetics? and ?representation? as concepts might pose in themselves?thus, asking: what might be the political consequences and implications when aesthetics cannot fully grasp or grapple with blackness and anti-blackness in the orders of politics, technologies, representation, or senses and sensibilities.
